content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a good challenge and it takes a good bit of thinking

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and do-able while still being challenging !
I rectified a bit the description, as I feel it was a bit confusing.

I think it's a clever clash, and I'd like it to be approved.

I just have a feeling that the "goal" section is a bit clumsy (that's a very subjective feeling!)

Wouldn't it be a bit clearer to explain it this way:
- You want to sort an array of numbers, A, from smallest to largest.
- Some of these numbers are fixed and can't be moved : they must remain at the same index in the sorted array.
- Those indexes are stored in a second array, B.

I'm not sure of the phrasing, but I guess switching the two lines:
"The numbers in an array B of the length M represent index numbers of A." 
and
"You cannot move the elements of A whose indexes are in B."
might make it clearer why there is a second array B. 

Again, this might be very subjective!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is an interesting and unusual one. It will provide a real challenge to players as it is not easily doable in under 5 minutes and will require them to put in some work.

I like this one. It does provide a challenge for clash of code, but it's very possible.

Goal:
* Try to immediately tell the user that A is an array: "You want to sort an array A, but you have a problem".
* The third sentence: you want to say "index numbers of A" instead of "the index numbers of A". The latter would mean that B contains all indexes, which means M == N. The former means that SOME index numbers of A are in B, not all of them.
* The fourth sentence is convoluted, and the content needs to be guessed at from the context. Maybe "You cannot move the elements of A whose indexes are in B." would be a good alternative.

Input:
* I suggest to not talk about arrays, but instead only tell the user that A and B are space-separated integers.

Output:
* Don't talk about arrays, tell the user that the puzzle expects space-separated integers.

Additional remarks:
* Maybe it would be a good idea to include tests with N > 10. I don't know how high it should go.

Input section
* Please add "space-separated integers" after [[A]] in line 2.
* Please add "space-separated integers" after [[B]] in line 4.

Thanks.

Thank you.
The sentences in the Input section are now more understandable.
I would like to remember how to say 'An array [[A]] space-separated integers', as I feel it is a common phrase. Thanks.

Thank you.
I changed the sentence.
I learned that it is important not to say the same thing more than necessary after first telling them it is an array.
I also learned that in the Output Section, it is not a good idea to write it as an array because I want the answers to be numbers separated by spaces, not arrays.
Also, in the actual program questions, I limited N to 100. It is quite a large number, but when I run the program, it seems to work well.

Thank you.
I have fixed the Goal Section statement.
I had you write a very good and clear Goal Section statement.Thanks.
I have changed a few things and replaced numbers with integers.

Thank you.
Oh, now I have fixed the description too.
My apologies for rewriting more of your rectifications.
I think it is probably still easy to understand. Thanks.

I think that's better, I just have 2 tiny suggestions:

Replace "You want to sort an array of integers, A, from smallest to largest." with "You want to sort [[A]] from smallest to largest."

I would have removed "but you have a problem" from the first sentence, and changed "Some of these integers are fixed and can't be moved : they must remain at the same index in the sorted array." to "However, some integers in [[A]] are fixed and can't be moved : they must remain at the same index in the sorted array."

I guess with these few changes it would be clear!

Thank you.
I have fixed the Goal Section statement.
I learned how to write in an easy-to-understand manner, which was a great learning experience. Thanks. (*'ω'*)

Yes, the important thing is to state the variable type. "Array" is not really a type in the stub generator, but integers/strings/floats are. And if more than one is stated in the same line, it is also important to state how they are separated from each other.

Thank you.
I learned for the first time that Array is not a type in the stub generator.
I will pay attention to a type description and write sentences from now on.
You can read all about the stub generator here: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/stub-generator

Thank you.
I always read a little bit when I was making the stub generator, but once again, reading it all, I have a much better understanding.
It was great to learn about things like gameloop, comments syntax, and how to use joins to combine text.

Oh, I think the stub generator I was looking at was the simplified version and not the documentation.
I compared the documentation with the simplified version and the documentation was much more detailed.
Thanks.
